data.title: Write a GDScript lexer for Pygments
data.body:
Since we're now using sphinx-doc to handle the Godot documentation, we can have syntax highlighting very easily using Pygments. But it obviously doesn't support GDScript yet, and falling-back to python3 is fine but not perfect (no highlighting for "var", "func", "extends", etc.).

So if we have some Python experts wanting to give it a try, here is the Pygments documentation about writing lexers: http://pygments.org/docs/lexerdevelopment/
The existing "python3" lexer could likely be taken as a base and enhanced (though it is likely far more advanced than what GDScript actually needs).

Once done, we would try to use it to generate our own doc, and also get it merged upstream in a future Pygments release.

data.body: There is a place for a link to http://www.godotengine.org/

data.title: Control Anchors Bug
data.body:
When using a Control node if you attempt to use the Ratio anchor mode, then attempt to modify the Margin associated with the Ratio anchor you will find that the Margin will not accept floating point values, instead it will only accept whole integers, however, this results in only being able to specify the ratio in "whole screen units", which obviously is not nearly as useful as being able to specify 0.2 of the width, etc.

![godotcontrolanchorbug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17059062/12864350/f34e15e0-cc55-11e5-8661-69c1ccde2ba6.png)

## 

I'm new to godot but am continuing to investigate a fix. Thanks!

data.title: Documentation Improvements (Long-term?)
data.body:
I've been reading through the website and I think it would be really great if there was a system that allowed users to submit improvements and updates to the documentation, for instance, I've seen a couple simple spelling mistakes in the documentation and yet, there isn't a direct way for me to improve the documentation currently (for instance like wikis provide).

Since this project is open-source it would be beneficial if users could submit improvements to the documentation, that way suddenly you get a ton more "editors" looking over the documentation for issues like spelling, punctuation, and even improvements, like, rewording a section of the documentation to clarify something that might be confusing to a beginner, such as knowledge that the original writer might have taken for granted.

For instance, on this page:
http://www.godotengine.org/projects/godot-engine/wiki/Creating_2D_Games

Within the first section of the page there are a few improvements that could be made, one, make the download link more prominent (did you find the link easily?).

Two, note the following line: 

> the game will be in 640x400 pixels resolution. This can be configured in the Project Settings (see previous tutorials)

I see two issues with this, first, tutorials should attempt to be as self-contained as possible. It would a small addition to the tutorial to add a line and an image showing how to modify the resolution of the game, even if it has been previously covered. However, the more egregious issue is that this line actively deceives the reader, if you follow the tutorials as they are currently setup on the website none of the previous tutorials have shown how to modify the resolution of the game. Once more, this is why tutorials ought to attempt to remain self-contained and reduce external references where possible. External references, and especially assumptions like, that greatly reduce the ability of the documentation to avoid logical issues when the documentation is modified over time.

In particular, each tutorial or piece of documentation has an intended audience, this particular piece of documentation is intended for very new beginners, and two very important steps are easy to either miss or be miss led by.

data.title: Added missing ReloadEmpty editor icon
data.body: Regression from 6349c50

data.title: Inspector Usability Improvement
data.body:
When working in the inspector it would be very convenient to be able to move between a series of input fields using the tab key. In the below image the Left Margin input field is currently selected, it would be a massive improvement in usability if you were able to hit tab to move to the next input field. Right now you have to either click between the different fields, yet, because of the slider that is often present you can't even conveniently click into the next field, meaning instead you have to hit enter then click the next input field, or you can choose to use the arrow keys and enter to move into the next field, both of which are far less convenient then a simple hit of the tab key.

![godottabtocontinue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17059062/12856163/77e22066-cc11-11e5-8134-9e08ae94c7fe.png)

data.title: SubClass as Custom types for export
data.body:
It'd be nice to be able to export a SubClass as a type of export and if you'd go into it and the exported variables from it would be accessible in the editor. 

Related, #3586, is requesting Typed Arrays from gdscript, which I'd also like to see SubClasses show up there.

```
class a():
    export var b = 0
    func _init(in):
        b = in

export(a) var custom_export
# export(array,a) var custom_export_array

```

data.title: Missing TileMap.get_cellv() method
data.body: The TileMap node has a `set_cellv(Vector2, tile)` method but its counterpart `get_cellv(Vector2)` is missing, there's only the `get_cell(x, y)` method. It's a minor issue but it's still annoying to have this inconsistency when working with tilemaps in vector coordinates.

data.title: Warning: ColorPicker gets too friendly
Allow using different script for the root node of an inherited scene
data.body:
This is a feature request.

Recently added feature of inheriting scene is very helpful, allowing us to derive slightly different scenes based on existing ones. It complements GDScript's extends mechanism to build on from existing code base. However, it doesn't look like these two features play well together yet.

Here's which I believe a typical scenario: I have a base character scene, with a root node KinematicBody and a script attached to it. Now, I can use "New Inherited Scene" and start adding new features (meaning, adding new nodes, which apparently I can) and so on, but this also means I need to add new behavior in the attached script. Unfortunately, the inherited scene and the base scene share the same script file, and it seems Godot doesn't (yet?) allow me to use a different script file for the root node of the inherited scene.

If it did, I could have simply use extends and build upon the base script. I think this is a necessary feature in order to have true inheritance.

data.title: Viewport mouse position only updated after touch release, not touch press.
data.body:
Here is the example I'm using: https://www.dropbox.com/s/bngu083qctasmal/example.tar.gz?dl=0

When a mouse button is pressed _**and held**_ on desktop the viewport.get_mouse_pos() function returns the correct position. On mobile, touching and holding does not update get_mouse_position until the touch is over. I feel this is slightly inconsistent.

This may be a duplicate of #1212

data.title: Fix missing comma

data.title: Exporting arrays of hints
data.body:
**TL;DR;** Support exporting of arrays with a given export hint, as in `export([], String, FILE)`

---

It would be nice if one can export an array of some export type, like an array of enums, an array of filepaths, etc. So, in other words, support not only:

``` gdscript
export(String, FILE) var file
export(NodePath) var nodepath
```

but also:

``` gdscript
export([], String, FILE) var files
export([], NodePath) var nodepaths
```

or even:

``` gdscript
export([], [], String, FILE) var files_2d_array
export([], [], NodePath) var nodepaths_2d_array
```

---

Because syntax needs some discussion, I would go on and propose a few variants:
- 1a. Square brackets (`[` and `]`) before other export parameters

``` gdscript
export([], String, FILE) var files
export([], [], float) var heights
export([], Array) var anything_array_2d
export([], []) var anything_array_2d # Or maybe not?
```
- 1b. Array before other export parameters

``` gdscript
export(Array, String, FILE) var files
export(Array, Array, float) var heights
export(Array, Array) var anything_array_2d
```
- 2a. Brackets after export parameters

``` gdscript
export(String, FILE)[] var files
export(float)[][] var heights
export[][] var anything_array_2d
```
- 2b. Brackets after export parameters, alteranative multi-dimetional

``` gdscript
export(float)[,] var heights
export[,] var anything_array_2d
```
- 3a. Brackets before export parameters

``` gdscript
export[](String, FILE) var files
export[][](float) var heights
export[][] var anything_array_2d # Same as 2a
```
- 3b. Brackets before export parameters, alteranative multi-dimetional

``` gdscript
export[,](float) var heights
export[,] var anything_array_2d # Same as 2b
```
- 4a. Plural inflections on params, disallowing multi-dimensional exports

``` gdscript
export(String, FILE)s var files
export(Array)s var anything_array_2d
# Can't export typed multidimenstional arrays, such as float[][]
```
- 4b. Plural inflections on keyword, disallowing multi-dimensional exports

``` gdscript
exports(String, FILE) var files
exports(Array) var anything_array_2d
# Can't export typed multidimenstional arrays, such as float[][]
```

As for my own preference, I like `1b` and `3a` the most, because I think they would match the current style. But `1a` isn't too bad either. I wouldn't go with any of `2b`, `3b`, `4a` or `4b`, as they don't match the style well enough.

---

P.S. I'm not looking for workarounds, and I know that they exist for `NodePaths` or 2D arrays. Also, some things like exported enums or file paths can't be really worked around without editor plugins for the moment.

P.P.S. There was a similar issue earlier #3388, but it wasn't as general as this one, and it got closed as it was asking for some way to assign resources (not any export type) in arrays.

data.title: support horizontal mouse wheel
data.body: fixes #3565. Only tested this on linux as I could not figure out how to emulate a horizontal wheel on windows.

data.title: Highlight integers and floats in script editor
data.body: Currently, integers and floats (if used in variables, constants, or independently) are not highlighted in any colour in the Godot script editor, whereas most other code editors do so. I guess we just need to find a nice color for it.

data.title: GDScript token functions (like `preload' or `yield') don't show up in the documentation
data.body:
It would be nice to have them appear and be documented in the @GDScript scope.
For example right now one can find documentation for `@GDScript.load`, but nothing about `preload`.

data.title: Add preload and PI to GDScript reserved keywords
data.body:
Thus enabling their syntactic colouring.
I also tried to sort the reserved words to make them easier to browse through when adding new ones of checking for missing ones.

Closes #3581.

data.title: Input Events in Viewports use the incorrect transform when it's a child of a Control
data.body:
All input events in a viewport are not adjusted based on the local transform of their parent control. It's the most noticeable on a GUI Control that is a child of the viewport itself. This causes all of the inputs to be way off if the control isn't sized to be the exact dimensions of the screen.

Additionally I can't seem to get kinematic rigidbody input picking to work correctly at _all_ (viewport or without), although that's probably a separate issue, and/or i'm doing something stupid.
- **Godot Version:** 2.0 Beta (also tried git build, same problem)
- **OS:** Windows 7 x64

---
#### Example scene

Here is a pretty simple example project with a self-contained scene (.tscn), where you will need to hover your mouse a little above the absolute center of the screen to click the button in the viewport.

[Test.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/116935/Test.zip)

screenshot of the bottom-right button showing a tooltip with the mouse super far away from it:

![2016-02-04_00-10-14](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4523300/12807301/e05fbe4e-cad3-11e5-8417-30486e1c2870.png)

data.title: Godot Editor Very Slow to Close
data.body: When I close the editor it takes an absurdly long time to shut itself down, the really annoying bit is that when this is going on you can't interact with the editor anymore meaning it's completely unresponsive while shutting down, which gives a very unsettling feeling to Godot's shutdown sequence as it makes me worry that Godot is about the crash or something similar.

data.title: Godot Project Manager Created Under the Windows Taskbar
data.body:
After the console is created it proceeds to spawn the Godot Project Manager, however, I like having my   taskbar at the top of my monitor, and when the Project Manager window is created it is positioned under the taskbar, which normally wouldn't be that big of an issue, but the location isn't remembered from run to run meaning it always appears in the same location. The real issue is that the windows header frame is completely under the task bar meaning that I have to always shift-click, select move, hit an arrow key, reposition. Technically, I don't need to move the window since nothing within the client I need to click is obscured, but to me its an annoying visual bug. The ideal fix would be to have the project manager remember its position between runs (and while your at it perhaps do the same for the editor).

Thank you for your time, and all your hard work on Godot, I really think Godot's got something special about it.

![godotcreatedunderwindows](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17059062/12806169/82d8975c-cad1-11e5-8b8c-cbc8c4a3c35d.png)

data.title: Event streams errors with XM modules.
data.body:
When trying to import xm module I get:

```
> ERROR: set_volume_fadeout: Condition ' p_amount>MAX_FADEOUT ' is true.
>    At: drivers/chibi/cp_instrument.cpp:133.
> ERROR: set_volume_fadeout: Condition ' p_amount>MAX_FADEOUT ' is true.
>    At: drivers/chibi/cp_instrument.cpp:133.
> ERROR: set_volume_fadeout: Condition ' p_amount>MAX_FADEOUT ' is true.
>    At: drivers/chibi/cp_instrument.cpp:133.
> ERROR: set_volume_fadeout: Condition ' p_amount>MAX_FADEOUT ' is true.
>    At: drivers/chibi/cp_instrument.cpp:133.
> ERROR: get_instrument: Index p_instrument out of size (MAX_INSTRUMENTS).
>    At: drivers/chibi/cp_song.cpp:349.
```

Testing XM module was created in MilkyTracker.
4 voices used with 4 instruments (one each), 1 sample in each instrument. Samples are stereo 16-bit 44100 wave files, approx. 30 sec long, imported with mixing channels option.
All 4 instruments are playing together, only one, long note at the beginning of the song first and only pattern. All of that is a 10Mb xm file.

At first few times Godot were just quitting after this errors.
After manipulating with playback mode in MilkyTracker, Godot was able to import the xm file and play it. The errors in console are still there.

May be related to https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/2553
